text: (upbeat music)
- Welcome to "Conversations With Leaders."

I'm Bryan Landerman and I'm
an AWS enterprise strategist.
And I'm joined today by Jack Berkowitz.
the chief data officer at ADP.

Jack, thanks for joining me.
- Thanks.
I'm really happy to be here.
- So tell me a little bit about your role.
- I kind of have a three-faceted role.
On the one hand,

it's really about protecting
the information, right?
So putting a strong data governance

around the data that we
have and managing that.

The second side, which
I spend a lot of time on

and really get energized
about is building products

using that information on
behalf of our clients, right?
And so we have people-analytics products,
we have other data products that we build

and I have a big engineering
team that does that.
And my third thing is really about

creating a data-literacy
culture inside of the company.
We're dealing with a lot of client data,
I mean, data's our middle name,
which is kind of corny, but true,
and so we're all about making sure
that everybody in the organization,

all 58,000 associates,
understand information,

and I really enjoy that
marketing side of things as well.
- Yeah, so that culture is a challenge
for a lot of customers

where data has typically kind
of been siloed and protected

and it's prevented us from
really getting value out of it.
So how are you approaching that?
What are you doing differently?
- Well, I'm not sure

that we're doing anything
drastically differently.
But what we are doing

is putting the knowledge
of governance around things
so everybody understands.
We don't want it to be siloed.

We want people to be able to
use the information they need

and at the same time, we
need to protect it, right?

'Cause it's data about
people or data about clients
and you wanna make sure

that it's well understood,
it's respected, you know?
And so, we have processes
and methods that we've put in place,

but at the same time, we
also bring it together
and make it accessible.

And so we're really spending
an awful lot of time

about getting it into a
single global-data platform,
getting all the data lineage there,
getting the data rights on top
so that people that need to use it

either for internal
analysis or to build product
or to service clients

'cause we have a large number
of our team servicing clients,

that they can get that
information really quickly.
- Yeah, that makes sense.
And I know you've been focusing a lot
on diversity, equity and inclusion,

really for your customers,
given your data sets.
So what's that journey been like?
- Well, it's been interesting, right?

There's a need in society,
there's a need in the US
to continue to push forward

with creating an inclusive
environment for everybody.
Right?

And the first way you do
that is by measuring it.

If you can't measure it,
then you have no idea
if you're actually making improvements
to people's situation or not.
And so a large portion of what we're doing

right now with that is
providing client companies
the ability to measure how they're doing.
And not only to measure it internally,
but then to use benchmarks

so that they can compare
themselves to other companies.

Right?
- I love that. Yeah.
- And are they doing well
in creating environments for people?
And that's not just bringing people in,

but are they also creating
opportunities for people

to thrive and grow inside
their organization?
- I couldn't agree more.
I think that baseline is really important
and I know you're creating that baseline
in a way that's keeping it
really relevant to that customer

so that you're not just
comparing them globally, but to-
- Exactly.

Right to the location
where they happen to be,

to the industry, to the
size of the company, right?
And again, we wanna make it
so that they can understand it quickly.
You know, not a lot of people

actually know everything
about statistics or numbers,
so we wanna be able to make it

so that it tells a story for
them and they can take action
because if they do wanna change things,
well, they don't know what to do.
So we have advice, we have expertise
right there in our product
so that they can take some action.
- That's fantastic.

And so obviously focus
on helping your customers
in this space.

What's that look like internally
for your organization?
- It's a great question.

So, as we build software,
we run it on ourselves.

We have 58,000 people
around the world, right?

- It's a good test bed.
- It's a good test bed.
It's a really good test bed.

And you know, some of
the things that we do
come from our ADP Research Institute

which is sort of a nonprofit
we have inside the company.
Some of it comes internally,

and then we implement
some of those programs.

One of the things that
we've been doing lately

in my engineering team is
providing people opportunities
that maybe, under some critical way,

well, they don't have all the
Xs and Os to make that happen

but you give 'em an opportunity
to thrive and to shine.
And this idea that people have to be given
that opportunity to rise
is something that we see in the research,
we can see it in the data,
so we're actually practicing it internally
and it is yielding wonderful results,

you know?
- Yeah, I love hearing that.

And you're right, we all
have a role to play in this
and so it's great to...
Visibility is step one,
so having those metrics and being able
to keep track of it is important.
- Yeah. Yeah, definitely.

You know, again, I run
data programs, right,
but I look across the corporation
and a lot of our data projects,
the leaders are actually women
and that's fantastic.

Right?
- It is.

- And so we're really
seeing the benefits there.
The company has a strong reputation
for really being a place
to attract diverse talent and cultivate

and it's something we believe
in strongly as a company

so it's really great to be able
to contribute the data side
of that to the company's story.
- So you're harnessing all of this data.

How are you re-architecting
your data in the cloud?
- That's a great question.

So, in mid 2019, we kind of
stepped back and we were looking

at how we were processing
the data on-prem.

And we had, you know,
sort of a lot of problems
just managing the demand of it all, right?
Like, to get time on the systems,

we had engineers staying up to
two and three in the morning,

just to timeshare,
right, to schedule jobs.

So we stepped back, we
worked with AWS and we said,

"Hey, we want to move
our data into the cloud."

And we did it for three
really important reasons.
The first thing was to be able
to get that elasticity of demand.
The second thing was to take advantage
of all the innovation, right?

So I could take advantage of
the new things from SageMaker

or whatever it happened
to be, very quickly.
And the third thing
was to really, really focus on the culture
and we started to do that

and we were kind of doing it
for a while and then COVID hit.
And, you know, it was interesting.

We had just gone live with
our very first capability

in February of 2020.
- Oh wow.

- And because we process all
that data about the workforce
and about pay, well, by the end of March,
we had to be up and running with reports
and all these other capabilities
to help really get our company operating

but really, loans and
small business capabilities

to all thousands and tens
of thousands of businesses.
And that really drove an awareness

about how we could use
the cloud for innovation.

And now what you see us doing
is innovating very quickly.
So the diversity dashboards
that I talked about this morning on stage
and then we just talked about here,

those things came to be in
a very short period of time

because people are now
thinking about data,

they're able to innovate and
they're able to get access
to the capabilities very quickly.

- I love that and I think
that that cultural piece
is such a big part.
You have to kind of see what's possible
to then start thinking differently
about how you can approach things

and innovate, yeah.
- That's right.

That's right, and so now we
have this explosion of ideas.
And really, our challenge,

and I think it's a
challenge of the industry,

is how do we put a
governance around the data,
the security, the privacy, the ethics
of using that information.

We've stood up an AI and
data ethics board at ADP
both for internal participants,

as well as we have some
external experts on that

to help us really think through
the use of the information
so that we're doing it properly.

And you know, putting the
right governance frameworks,
and I keep using that phrase.
It so important as we move forward.
And it's actually...

You know, taking the time
to put that in place,
actually increases our pace overall.
- Mm. Yeah, I mean, right.
Having the guardrails and kind of knowing

what those guardrails are does
actually create more speed

than you might think.
- Yeah, right.

You know, people think,
"Well, if I'm gonna do that,
I'm gonna slow down."
It's exactly the opposite.
If you do that, you have it structured,

people can get to it, and
then you feel confident
so you can actually execute very quickly.
- Awesome.
Well, Jack, sounds like you guys

are making a real difference
for your customers
and your company with your data platform.
Thanks so much for joining me today.

I appreciate it.
- Thank you.
It's been great being here.
(upbeat music)
